prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "Am I the Asshole" (AITA) post is in the wrong. The situation is about ending free friend rides in their car.

The friend regularly rides with the author, and the author handles all the gas costs. This time, the friend put in $10 of gas because the author forgot their purse. The author then told the friend to find their own way around. The question is if the author is wrong for ending this arrangement.

First, I need to consider the context. The friend has used the car hundreds of times without contributing to gas. This time, they did contribute, but the author is ending the rides. The main point is whether the author is being unreasonable.

The author's actions might be seen as standing up for their own boundaries. The friend didn't usually pay, so maybe the author felt it was unfair to cover all the gas costs. The act of the friend putting gas this time might not be enough to justify continuing the rides, especially if the author wants to set a boundary. 

On the other hand, the friend might feel that since they contributed this time, it's unfair to stop picking them up. But the author is making a point that the friend should find their own transportation. 

I think the key here is that the author is setting a boundary after the friend's one-time contribution. Since the friend hadn't contributed before, the author isn't being unreasonable. The author isn't in the wrong because they're asserting their right to not let others take advantage of them. So the answer would be B (No).
